title: Instructor • ASL 1.7 — Describing People

pacing.notes: Warm welcome + purpose: 'We’ll describe people using noun+adjective order.'
Model TALL, SHORT, YOUNG, OLD, HAPPY, SAD. Emphasize adjectives follow nouns.
Choral + small-group descriptions; correct adjective placement.
Explain portfolio clip expectations and rubric.

iepUdl: Multiple engagement: choice of who to describe

coachPhrases: Notice how your eyebrows and eye gaze support clarity—keep that.
Try noun first, then adjective: 'HE TALL' instead of 'TALL HE'.
Great handshape! Let’s slow wrist movement for 'OLD'.

teachingTips: Stand slightly angled so students see dominant hand clearly.
Use two contrasting examples rapidly (HAPPY vs SAD) to anchor memory.
If English word order leaks in, gesture 'swap' and re-model.

formativeChecks.prompt: Adjectives go… before or after noun?
Gloss 'SHE YOUNG HAPPY' (students write then sign).

quiz.q: Where do adjectives usually go in ASL?
Sign for describing someone as old?

accommodations: Provide front-row seating and high-contrast background.
Allow student to pre-record description if live signing increases anxiety.

portfolio.feedbackStem: I noticed your adjective order was __. Next, try __.

checklist: Modeled each target sign from at least two angles
Captured exit slip or quick demo from each pair
